intro: Baeothryon planifolium, commonly known as the flat-leaved baeothryon, is a member of the Apiaceae family, characterized by its aromatic foliage and umbellate inflorescences. It is native to southern Africa, particularly South Africa, where it thrives in rocky and sandy soils. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with lanceolate, flat leaves that are often covered in fine hairs. Its flowers are small and white, arranged in compound umbels, and it produces small, dry fruits known as schizocarps. Baeothryon planifolium is often found in open habitats such as grasslands and along riverbanks, where it contributes to local biodiversity.
